H0.text: A great land bridge once connected the continents is the least likely explanation for two fossils of the same species found on two different continents separated by the Atlantic Ocean, both dated to be 2 million years old.

H1.text: The remains were carried by ocean currents is the least likely explanation for the finding of two 2‑million‑year‑old fossils of the same species on continents separated by the Atlantic Ocean.

H2.text: A single landmass once existed with both continents is the least likely explanation for two 2‑million‑year‑old fossils of the same species found on two continents separated by the Atlantic Ocean.

H3.text: The animals swam across the ocean is the least likely explanation for discovering two 2‑million‑year‑old fossils of the same species on continents separated by the Atlantic Ocean.

A5.text: There is also living evidence, with the same animals being found on two continents.

A6.text: Benjamin Franklin (1782) and Ralph Waldo Emerson (1834) noted Continental Drift

A7.text: A brief introduction to Plate Tectonics, based on the work of Alfred Wegener

A10.text: It is very difficult to match up rock beds that are not directly adjacent due to faults and erosion.

A11.text: The law of superposition that states that in undeformed stratigraphic sequences the oldest strata will lie at the bottom of the sequence, while newer material stacks upon the surface.

A12.text: The principle of original horizontality that states layers of sediments will originally be deposited horizontally under the action of gravity.
